apple_why: Also on a similar journey, going plant-based rather than full vegetarian or vegan (main goal is to cut out processed food, simple carbs and as much meat as possible). I’ve tried many delivery services and get bored within 1 month as they tend to repeat. The best solution that was sustainable for me is Whole Foods 2 hour delivery with prime. Their frozen stuff is so high quality, I buy frozen root vegetables, vegetable mixes, Gardein fake meat protein. Trader Joe’s is my go-to if I have time to go to the store. I make it a point to tell people I’m plant based (and NOT vegan). I’ve found many vegans are on the hunt for products to replace regular products (vegan cheese, vegan sour cream)- but I worry about the processed nature of these. Cheers :)

lekhavnv: I don’t find delivery services filling or economic. Also, they don’t have the type of cooking that works best for my body. Build a good pantry of items, and easy cooking will follow.

rosy_._mona: Lifelong vegetarian but not a vegan. Most grocery delivery services have a vegetarian or vegan option. You have to shop around a little to find one that fits your taste. I tried blue Apron for a while and was unimpressed. I loved plated but they went out of business. I'm on Marley Spoon now and it's pretty good but they use quite a bit of pasta. In your own grocery shopping, invest in lentil flour pastas. Trader Joe's has an excellent lentil spaghetti. Talk to a nutritionist because they are largely under utilized resource for recipes and strategies like journaling. Remember in this journey, your satisfaction and fulfillment are a priority. If you don't feel satisfied or fulfilled, you need to pay attention to this and question it. This is when a journal can aid your journey. Good luck.
